title: General Election before Christmas if MPs vote down Boris’s Brexit plan
text:
The PM has not ruled out pulling his bill altogether (Picture: PA)

British voters could be going to the polls before the end of the year if Parliament reject the Prime Minister’s EU Withdrawal Bill.

Boris Johnson’s has told MPs to back his Brexit deal to avoid a no-deal departure and ‘move out country on’ as he kicked-off a Commons showdown today.

His allies have refused to rule out the ‘nuclear option’ of pulling the Brexit deal completely if it’s changed beyond all recognition through amendments in the commons.

Two crucial votes this evening will determine whether the PM will be able to live up to his ‘do or die’ commitment to take the UK out of the European Union by the October 31 deadline.

MPs will cast their initial vote on Withdrawal Agreement Bill (WAB) before being asked to back his accelerated timetable to hurry legislation through Parliament.

Opening the debate, he told colleagues he has been forced to ‘accelerate our preparations’ for a no-deal Brexit after they voted to delay his deal in Parliament on Saturday.

MPs will vote tonight on a ‘programme motion’ on whether to accept the PMs proposals to push the legislation through Parliament in three days.

A Downing Street spokesperson told the BBC: ‘If Parliament votes again for delay by voting down the programme motion, and the EU offers delay until 31 Jan, then we will pull the Bill.

‘There will be no further business for Parliament and we’ll move to an election before Christmas.’

More to follow.
